document.title: South Dakota Social Studies Standards Adopted April 17, 2023

C87F873C53504008A24470365558FE90.description:
The student tells the story of the French and Indian War, especially the roles of George
Washington and Benjamin Franklin, and its effect on American identity and sense of unity. H

62D6292F4C254D588F5BDDF07807203C.description:
The student explains the rule of law, as asserted in the Magna Carta, compared to the rule of
man, and its influence on leading colonists. HC

5AF15B0559E64BB8BA392AB503A780EA.description:
The student explains how England’s relationship toward the colonists amounted to a “salutary
neglect” and the ways this relationship benefitted the colonists. HC

9D5C3B191932482ABD130A1DC5039160.description:
The student explains how the “American” colonist was generally defined by certain traits,
including being hard-working, determined, religious, skeptical of authority, and self-governing.
HCE

160177E303C248DE8B64D6E724D47B73.description:
The student explains the status and effects of each of the following in colonial society, and the
extents to which these were the rare in history: private property, education, local selfgovernment, and religious freedom. HCE

58A6B6956E0C4F6DB7BFAA57BFD99662.description:
The student explains the colonial economies and ways of life among the New England, Middle,
and Southern colonies. E

3CFA5F3EDD834C30AC369E8D83922E6B.description: The student describes life on a slave ship in the Middle Passage. H

7D8446AC374E428BB1DF9D925843CACD.description: The student explains the Triangle Trade. H

E36C69582BF9403CAC072ACB316837A8.description: The student demonstrates knowledge of colonial America.

67D622D6C219474CB66AD7B02B482570.description:
The student tells of the founding of the following colonies: Connecticut, Rhode Island, New
York, Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Georgia. H

731651ABCAC64039AA555ED09B07AA16.description: the meaning of John Winthrop’s “city upon a hill”

40A5D7AC8411422C9E85CA9FDD88F9B9.description: the backgrounds and motivations of the Mayflower passengers

A3B164AD69264513B8C846A8D9750940.description: the stories of William Bradford and John Winthrop

210D8D8B306B48B9AA9CBAE5772D6F0C.description: The student tells the story of the founding of Plymouth and Massachusetts Bay, including: HC

3249137BCC124CC7AFFCE5480F1384D4.description: the arrival of Africans from a Dutch slave ship captured by the English

E380CD88AF0545CEA600E16DAED9E29B.description: the stories of John Smith, Matoaka (Pocahontas), and John Rolfe

EB85B811AEA14D44B72C73ADF2EBFF04.description: The student tells the story of the founding of Jamestown, including: H

3748FB525EE84B32BD41060A88C040F8.description:
The student explains the variety of cooperative and violent interactions between Europeans,
Indigenous peoples, and among Indigenous tribes. H

D6D7ACFD0D974FFCBFDDBEF2E6AC8692.description:
The student explains the Columbian Exchange of resources, people, and disease, including
how smallpox decimated Native Americans. HE

F877B30739E14269ADB3BEEC3BE01BB8.description:
The student describes the travels and discoveries of other explorers in the future United
States, including Ponce de Leon, Samuel de Champlain, and Henry Hudson. H

BFA525596EB440BF9FD269618577D7D6.description: The student explains the origin of the name “America.” H

2C140DA7CFD44A13AC56A97C9F2641CE.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge of European exploration and settlement of what would
become the United States.

F0A982D3936A4149808D57FF1811F52B.description: his death in poverty and humiliation

E719E4E3EEDD497EA3CC4A5BCBB2ADA4.description: his theories about a faster western route to Asia

B2EAB0050034460BAA396A531252DB56.description: The student tells the biography of Christopher Columbus, including: H

020D1B8E89D24C83838E437BF00E611C.description:
The student explains the history of slavery from ancient times through the 15th century slave
trade among Africans, Arabs, and Europeans, and compares it to the practice of indentured
servitude. H

C3AB4BF0F8034ADBBB69265069A935B1.description: The student explains the various European motivations for exploration. H

F5970701E4E94C8385FF7A1946892B65.description: The student locates Jamestown, Plymouth, and Boston on a map. G

13EA5A55E8EC4A0DA9166C9981D275E4.description:
The student explains the tribal organizational structures of present-day Native Americans in
South Dakota as sovereign nations. C

46B40E2B52294FF9B0D7E6927A34E7FF.description:
The student describes the similarities and differences in lifestyle, traditional warfare, and
culture between two historical or present Native American tribes, one of which is from South
Dakota, such as the Oceti Sakowin Oyate (including select standards from Oceti Sakowin
Essential Understandings 1-5 and 7), Mandan, Sahnish (Arikara), Cheyenne, Crow, Otoe, and
Hidatsa. H

055BEBE137D9416F961ED6E83964BC04.description: The student describes the Ancestral Pueblo and Hopewell civilizations. H

DD5D9748098344D3B8AC055BFBCF9F58.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge of Native Americans and the voyages of Christopher
Columbus.

2A0E70E94B6243D0A30B5735208928FC.description:
The student explains the causes, warfare, and effects of the Punic Wars, including the roles of
Hannibal and Scipio Africanus. H

D6DE076814304F1AA5B7E9E1BEDD3D6B.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of Rome, including in
architecture, engineering, sculpture, the Latin language, and republican institutions and
practices. HC

B2E69B87F8AF43D3BEF4F7EAE6A39059.description:
The student explains the stories and events surrounding the founding of Rome and the Roman
Republic. H

D834AA47091F4152995A84CC31682969.description:
The student tells of the conquests of Alexander of Macedon and the spread of Greek culture in
the Hellenistic Period. H

4DD7BD7C0D7C4096BC8A15F92FCEEDC3.description: The student explains the causes, warfare, and effects of the Peloponnesian War. H

8550CDBC3684438EAF3E0FA28F6978C0.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of Athens, including
pottery, architecture, sculpture, drama, and democratic institutions and practices. H

CC081CD343F9492E898C5D8DD1C5C72F.description:
The student explains the causes, warfare, and effects of the Persian Wars, including the
battles of Marathon and Thermopylae. H

65ACF3D306D94391AA3B1ED78EA0C05F.description: The student identifies the major figures and stories within Greek and Roman mythology. H

7E0C65D3A21043AE94A0E62F6C53026B.description: The student demonstrates knowledge of Ancient Greece and the Roman Republic.

0561D6981DA947D8A3FC31A872B053C4.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, and stories of the ancient
Hebrews. H

EAAA9B5E54FD44D8A68A97728305B1C8.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and civil
contributions of Ancient Egypt, including agriculture, the calendar, hieroglyphic writing, and
papyrus. HCE

C9838948E272438A8E9312D0B8D8C901.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and civil
contributions of Ancient India, Babylon, Persia, and Ancient China, including polytheism,
metalsmithing, the domestication of animals, and inventions such as the wheel, plow, and
writing. HCE

D4D53329755D43D1A02E4335FDBE3B79.description:
The student explains the roles of climate and environmental changes, hunter-gatherer
societies, metallurgy, and agriculture in the development of early civilizations. HCE

9CE38B5A615342A8B63C58532765086E.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge of ancient civilizations in Asia, the Middle East, and Northern
Africa.

052B0A0FB498428695E50FA69F7315AD.description: The student locates on a map the following geographic features of South Dakota: G

23AE0ADD28F742558C64AC5BAC09F489.description: The student locates on a map the major reservations in South Dakota. G

54D0DFE70EFC4ECF8A724EFC7C601C83.description:
The student locates South Dakota, Pierre, Rapid City, and Sioux Falls on a map and spells their
names correctly. G

6594C4098ECC4A4E885009588D6A6EF0.description: The student locates Washington, D.C. on a map and identifies it as our nation’s capital. G

B0FF0CE762DC44528880B95048C3C7EA.description:
The student locates New York City and Philadelphia on a map and spells their names correctly.
G

DDF77D79F6DF48B7B711109D80B55E8C.description: The student locates on a map the major regions of the United States, including: G

0150A531702746B89D938C95B0A82C0B.description: The student locates on a map all fifty states in America. G

00B7D942D4FF4C9D80F8C67DFFB0CD16.description:
The student locates on a map and describes the features of America’s physical geography,
including: G

8E55062C07E74939A502AA76671F03F0.description: The student demonstrates knowledge of American and South Dakota geography.

53EAF13C9E904E6A8141181E88D5719A.description: The student can investigate a historical figure through writing an informative paragraph. H

235FA5F1DE9A48FEB6B6E9EE543756A7.description: The student can evaluate a historical event through writing a narrative paragraph. H

549EC02BA1DF4F9BBB668F2E7F4BC256.description:
As preparation for study of the American Revolution, but not limited to that study, the student
can demonstrate how taxes work using counters, drawings, or mathematics. E

9C2B2B46BA4D4E61B1E5B6299D42DD8D.description: The student can correctly use terms related to time periods or dates in history, including: H

1801221B38BD4693963D2EDBADF38170.description:
Building upon skills learned in previous grades, the student learns the skills to complete the following
tasks, completing each task with relative ease by the end of 3rd grade.
